Formation of iron active species on HZSM-5 catalysts by varying iron precursors for phenol hydroxylation Siriphorn Buttha a Sujittra Youngme a Jatuporn Wittayakun b Sirinuch Loiha a ⁎ a Materials Chemistry Research Center, Department of Chemistry and Center of Excellence for Innovation in Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Khon Kaen University, Khon Kaen 40002, Thailand Materials Chemistry Research Center Department of Chemistry and Center of Excellence for Innovation in Chemistry Faculty of Science Khon Kaen University Khon Kaen 40002 Thailand b School of Chemistry, Institute of Science, Suranaree University of Technology, Nakhon Ratchasima, 30000, Thailand School of Chemistry Institute of Science Suranaree University of Technology Nakhon Ratchasima 30000 Thailand ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Iron-containing HZSM-5 zeolite (Fen+-HZSM-5) are performed by ion exchange method with varying iron precursors of Fe2+, Fe3+ and equivalent molar of Fe2+/Fe3+. The Fen+-HZSM-5 materials are used as catalysts for phenol hydroxylation in the presence of H2O2. Bulk-iron oxides of α-Fe2O3 and α-FeOOH are synthesized via hydrothermal method for catalytic comparison to Fen+-HZSM-5. The iron structures on the Fen+-HZSM-5 catalysts are determined using UV–vis DRS and EXAFS techniques. The iron species found in the Fe2+-HZSM-5 and Fe3+-HZSM-5 catalysts is an isolated Fe3+ ion in tetrahedral geometry. Iron-oxo bonds with oxygen in zeolite framework (Fe-OF) are identified on both catalysts. On the other hand, Fe-O bond distances and coordination number on Fe2+/Fe3+-HZSM-5 exhibit the mixture of iron-oxo and iron-dioxo species (FO-Fe-OF) in octahedral geometry. The present iron species in the Fe2+/Fe3+-HZSM-5 catalyst show a significant improvement of the turnover number (TON) for phenol hydroxylation in comparison to the bulk α-Fe2O3 and α-FeOOH catalysts. Moreover, the existent iron-dioxo species on the Fe2+/Fe3+-HZSM-5 catalyst enhances catalytic selectivity to catechol product. Keywords HZSM-5 α-Fe2O3 α-FeOOH EXAFS Phenol hydroxylation 1 Introduction Catechol (CAT) and hydroquinone (HQ) named dihydroxybenzene (DHB) are well known as novel chemicals produced by catalytic reaction of phenol hydroxylation with hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) as oxidant [1]. CAT is mostly used as agrichemicals, polymerization inhibitor, synthesis of aroma chemicals, etc. while HQ is used as an antioxidant in elastics, pigment, etc [2,3]. Performances of homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts for phenol hydroxylation via Fenton-like reaction have been widely reported [4–6]. The heterogeneous catalysis is preferable due to an easy catalyst-product separation, favorable activity and selectivity [7]. The bulk transition metal oxides such as Fe2O3, Fe3O4, Co3O4 and MnO3 were reported as simple catalysts for phenol hydroxylation [8–12]. However, these oxides had poor catalytic activity and low DHB selectivity due to low surface area and easy loss of active component on the catalysts in acidic condition. Moreover, the relevant of particle size of the active component and phenol conversion was obviously observed by Xiong et al. [13]. Dispersion of the transition metals on microporous materials of zeolites such as Cu-Y, Fe-MOR, Ti-ZSM-5, Fe-ZSM-5 and Mn-BEA have been extensively investigated [7,9,14–16]. Fe-containing zeolite (Fe-ZSM-5) catalysts have attracted much attention for phenol hydroxylation due to their redox property and environmental friendliness. Their catalytic efficiency is considerably dependent on chemical composition, preparation method and type of dispersed-metal species on catalyst support [17]. In addition, particle size and ion exchange location of the metal species on porous supports strongly affect their activity and selectivity to DHB products. Moreover, pore opening Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts are great interest due to the coke reduction property by substantially improving the internal mass transport rate of phenol and thus retarding the catalyst deactivation [18]. To increase the pore opening Fe-ZSM-5, minimization of iron oxide particle size by varying preparation conditions is interest. However, it is still unclear which Fe species is responsible for catalytic activity of phenol hydroxylation and how zeolites influence the dispersed Fe structures. The iron oxides species of α-Fe2O3 and Fe3O4 located on extra-framework sites of zeolites could be performed by various techniques [11,12,19] such as ion exchange, impregnation and precipitation methods depending upon the expected iron species and iron content. Nechita et al. [19] suggested that the coexist small Fe size in Fe-containing zeolites of isolated, dimeric, oligomeric Fe sites and oxy/hydroxide FexOy(OH)n aggregates always perform by the such various methods. These present small Fe species in extra-framework zeolites indicates high surface area of active sites. It has been reported that Fe2+ ion is an active species for phenol hydroxylation. Besides, the active catalyst of Fe3O4 containing Fe2+/Fe3+ mixture is also reported through redox pair reaction [11]. The existence of iron-valence on the zeolite surface is strongly dependent on preparation methods, iron precursors and treatment condition. The Fe2+ species could be generally prepared from a ferrous salt. Moreover, with thermal treatment of Fe3+ precursor the mixture of Fe2+/Fe3+ ions in the same sample is possibly performed [19]. Furthermore, the coordination number of the Fe3+ species also influences the catalytic performance for phenol hydroxylation as reported by Villa et al. [15] and Liang et al. [20]. Tetrahedral Fe3+ incorporated in mesoporous silica and ZSM-5 framework is reported as active site for phenol hydroxylation to yield high selectivity to DHB products. The catalytic mechanism for phenol hydroxylation proceeding through redox reaction of Fe2+/Fe3+ ion pairs has been proposed as shown in Scheme 1 . Superoxide radical ( OOH) and Fe2+ are primarily created by the reaction of H2O2 with Fe3+. The superoxide radical and Fe2+ consequently react to produce hydroxyl radical ( OH) for the proceeding hydroxylation through a Fenton-like reaction [21]. This article presents the synthesis of Fen+-HZSM-5 via the ion exchange method by using different Fe precursors of isolated and mixture of ferrous (Fe2+) and ferric (Fe3+) ions. Variation of the iron structures relevant to precursors are investigated using UV–vis DRS and XAS analysis. Roles of the iron structures on catalytic performance for phenol hydroxylation of Fen+-HZSM-5 are examined in comparison to the synthesized bulk-iron oxides of α-Fe2O3 and α-FeOOH catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Rice husk was obtained from a local rice mill in Kalasin Province, Thailand. Hydrochloric acid (37 wt% HCl, Carlo-Erba), sodium aluminate anhydrous (55–56% NaAlO2, Sigma-Alorich), sodium hydroxide (97 wt% NaOH, RCI Labscan), ammonium carbonate ((NH4)2CO3, Panreac), iron nitrate nona hydrate (Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, Merck), ferrous sulfate (FeSO4·7H2O, Carlo erba), tetrapropylammonium bromide (99% C12H28BrN or TPABr, Acros Organics), sulfuric acid (95–97% H2SO4, Merck), phenol pellet (99% C6H6O, Panreac) and hydrogen peroxide (30% H2O2, Merck) were used as received without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of rice husk silica (RHS) The RHS was prepared following a procedure reported by Loiha et al. [22]. Dried rice husk was refluxed in 3 HCl at 80–85 °C for 6 h to remove traces of other inorganic content besides silica. After treatment, the rice husk was washed several times with DI water until neutral and dried at 110 °C overnight. Finally, the rice husk was calcined in a muffle furnace at 550 °C for 6 h. White powder of RHS was obtained. 2.3 Synthesis of HZSM-5 zeolite ZSM-5 zeolite in sodium form (NaZSM-5) with Si/Al ratio of 16 was synthesized by a method modified from the literature [23]. TPABr was used as an organic template to assist the formation of the zeolite framework. RHS and NaAlO2 were used as silicon and aluminum sources, respectively. RHS was dissolved in a NaOH solution and sequentially added TPABr to perform sodium silicate solution. The NaAlO2 solution with the desired Si/Al ratio was primarily prepared, and then slowly dropped into the sodium silicate solution with vigorously stirred for 3 h. Gelation of the mixture was obtained by adjusting pH to 11 using NaOH and H2SO4. The mixed gel was transferred to a stainless steel autoclave with Teflon liner (200 mL) and crystallized at 170 °C for 72 h. The solid product was separated by centrifugation and neutralized by washing with DI water. The as-synthesized powder was dried and calcined at 550 °C for 5 h to remove the organic template. NaZSM-5 zeolite was converted to proton form (HZSM-5) by refluxing with (NH4)2CO3 at 80 °C for 6 h. The obtained ammonium form ZSM-5 powder, NH4-ZSM-5, was washed with distilled water until neutral then dried and calcined in air at 400 °C for 4 h. HZSM-5 zeolite was obtained after calcination. 2.4 Preparation of Fen+-HZSM-5 catalysts Fen+-HZSM-5 catalysts were prepared by ion exchange of individual Fe2+ and Fe3+ ions and equivalent molar of Fe2+/Fe3+ mixture using FeSO4·7H2O and Fe(NO3)3·9H2O precursors. 1.5 g of zeolite support was added to the precursor solution (0.1 M, 20 mL) and refluxed at 50 °C for 22 h under N2 gas. After refluxing, the iron-supported zeolite powder was separated by centrifugation, washed with DI water until neutral then dried and calcined at 400 °C for 4 h. The catalysts of Fe2+-HZSM-5, Fe3+-HZSM-5 and Fe2+/Fe3+-HZSM-5 were obtained. 2.5 Synthesis of bulk hematite (α-Fe2O3) and goethite (α-FeOOH) The goethite was synthesized by the hydrothermal method. About 4.85 g of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O and 2.73 g of KOH were dissolved in 10 mL of DI water. The Fe(NO3)3·9H2O solution was added dropwise to the KOH solution under vigorous stirring. The resulting mixture was loaded into a stainless steel autoclave with Teflon liner (200 mL) and filled with water to 80% of the total volume and aged at 100 °C for 6 h. The solid product was washed with DI water and absolute ethanol before drying at 50 °C for 12 h. The hematite was synthesized by the hydrothermal method following the procedure reported by Wang et al. [24] using Fe(NO3)3·9H2O precursor. 5.4 g of the iron precursor was dissolved in 60 mL DI water and adjusted to pH 9 by ammonia solution (NH3·H2O). The mixture was transferred to a stainless steel autoclave with Teflon-liner (200 mL) and aged at 150 °C for 5 h. The product was washed with DI water and absolute ethanol before drying at 50 °C. 2.6 Characterization of the catalysts Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded by a PANalytical EMPYREAN diffractometer using Cu Kα (1.5406 Å) radiation with a step size of 0.02° in the 2θ range of 5–80°. Transmission electron microscopic (TEM) images were obtained on a Tecnai G220 operating at 200 kV (FEI). The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were obtained by a Micromeritics ASAP 2010 after degassing at 300 °C for 3 h. The BET surface areas were determined in the P/P0 range of 0.01–0.998. The UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra (UV–vis DRS) of the solid samples were conducted in the range of 200–800 nm with a Shimadzu UV-VIS-NIR3101PC scanning spectrophotometer using an integrated sphere. The analysis of iron content in the catalysts was carried out using atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS) via a Perkin Elmer AAnalyst 100 spectrometer with air-acetylene flame. For these measurements the catalysts were dissolved in hot aqua regia containing several drops of hydrofluoric acid (HF). Extended X-ray absorption structure (EXAFS) and X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) were conducted in the transmission mode at Beamline 1.1 W, Synchrotron Light Research Institute (SLRI). Each XANE and EXAFS spectrum was scanned with energy steps of 0.2 and 1.0 eV, respectively, without any pretreatment steps. An interactive program for XAFS analysis of IFEFFIT package software including Athena and Artemis programs was used. 2.7 Catalytic testing for phenol hydroxylation The phenol hydroxylation was carried out in a 250 mL two-necked round bottom flask fitted with a water-cooled condenser. 5.6 g phenol and 60 mL DI and 0.09 g catalyst were added into round bottom flask and continuously stirred at 70 °C for 30 min. H2O2 (30%) was slowly added to the mixture by syringe use with the molar ratio of H2O2 : phenol of 2 : 1 under vigorous stirring at 70 °C. The mixed solution was collected at 0, 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 60, 90, 150, 210 and 390 min and filtered through 0.22 μm nylon membranes for product analysis. The filtrate was analyzed by gas chromatography (GC), Agilent, GC7890B model with HP-5 capillary column and flame ionization detector (FID) using the internal standard of toluene. The percentages of the phenol conversion (X phenol), product distribution, dihydroxybenzene yield (Y DHB) and turnover number (TON) were calculated by the following equations. X phenol ( % ) = n phenol 0 − n phenol n phenol 0 × 100 Product distribution ( % ) = n CAT or n HQ n CAT + n HQ × 100 Y DHB ( % ) = m DHB,Actual m DHB,Theoretical × 100 TON = n phenol 0 x Y DHB n Fe n°phenol and n phenol are the initial and final molar concentration of phenol, respectively. n CAT and n HQ are molar concentration of catechol and hydroquinone products, respectively. m DHB is mass (g) of dihydroxybenzenes (catechol and hydroquinone). n Fe is the molar concentration of Fe in each catalyst. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical property of catalysts The XRD patterns of HZSM-5 and Fen+-HZSM-5 catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 . All Fen+-HZSM-5 catalysts exhibited typical diffraction peaks of the ZSM-5 zeolite corresponded to literatures [25–31] indicating structural stability of the HZSM-5 support after Fe loading. However, the main peak positions of the Fen+-HZSM-5 were systematically shifted to higher values relating to a decrease of d-spacing between lattices of the zeolite crystal. The contraction in a lattice parameter of zeolite is possibly relevant to interaction between the iron ions (Fen+) and oxygen atoms in the zeolite framework (OF). No crystalline phases of bulk iron oxides were detected by XRD on all samples indicating the presence of either small crystalline size or amorphous phase of iron species on the zeolite surface [31–33]. The Fe content in Fen+-HZSM-5 determined by AAS is reported in Table 1 . The different iron contents on the catalysts depending on iron precursors were observed. About 2.0 wt% of Fe content was observed on Fe2+-HZSM-5 and Fe2+/Fe3+-HZSM-5 catalysts while the Fe content on the Fe3+-HZSM-5 catalyst was about 1.3 wt %. The low iron content on Fe3+/HZSM-5 is probably due to surface saturation by strong adsorbed species of isolated Fe3+ on BrØnsted acid sites of HZSM-5 [8]. This result indicated good dispersion of iron on the zeolite surface without proceeding of particle agglomeration. Whereas, high iron content observed on the catalysts prepared form Fe2+ and mixed Fe2+/Fe3+ precursors was due to high particle agglomeration of iron oxide species on the HZSM-5 surface. The plausible iron species on ZSM-5 support depending on iron precursors was proposed by Marturano et al. [34]. The Fe-ZSM-5 samples were prepared by chemical vapor deposition (CVD) using on Fe2+ and Fe3+ precursors. Binuclear [HO-Fe-O-Fe-OH]2+ clusters located at the ion exchange positions of the zeolite was found by Fe3+ precursor. While, the iron hydroxide ([Fe(OH)2]+) and iron oxide ([FeO]+) located in ion exchange sites of zeolite were detected using Fe2+ precursors. These hydroxide and oxide species could be aggregated to Fe2O3 and Fe3O4 clusters with high Fe loading besides the above-mentioned binuclear species. Therefore, the iron oxide particles are highly agglomerated in present of Fe2+ precursor. UV–vis DRS spectra of the samples were conducted in a wavelength range of 200–800 nm as shown in Fig. 2 . The deconvolution of each sub-band area in all spectra was calculated using the Gaussian curve fitting. There were three fitting characteristic regions in Fen+-HZSM-5 spectra. The intense bands in the ranges of 200–250 nm and 250–300 nm were attributed to isolated Fe3+ species in tetrahedral and octahedral coordination, respectively [28,35–37]. The band in the range of 300–400 nm was assigned to octahedral Fe3+ in oligomeric FexOy and clusters in the zeolite channels [38]. Bands above 400 nm were attributed to Fe2O3 particles on the external surface of the zeolite [35,39]. Contribution in the peak area of the absorption spectrum is shown in Table 2 where I1 , I2 and I3 represented the area (%) of sub-bands at λ range 200–300, 300–400 and 400–650 nm, respectively. The major components observed on Fe2+-HZSM-5 and Fe3+-HZSM-5 were isolated Fe species (65–75%). Besides, the iron oxide clusters and large particles were found as minor components. Whereas, the accumulated clusters and large particles of iron oxides were determined as the major components on the Fe2+/Fe3+-HZSM-5 sample. Aggregation of the Fe2+/Fe3+ redox couple might due to chain propagation of –(Fe3+-O-Fe2+OH) species during ion exchange, large particles of iron oxides could be obtained after calcination [45]. XANES is a fingerprint technique that allows identification of the oxidation state and coordination environment of a Fe-absorbing atom. The normalized XANES profiles in Fe K-edge of the Fen+-HZSM-5 catalysts comparing with Fe3+ standards of hematite (α-Fe2O3) and goethite (α-FeOOH) are shown in Fig. 3 . The Fe K-edge conducted in α-Fe2O3 and α-FeOOH were 7125.6 and 7127.1 eV, respectively, indicating Fe3+ valent state. The lower edge energy of Fe3+ in α-Fe2O3 corresponded to lower electron deficient of the Fe species than that of α-FeOOH. The XANES profiles of the Fen+-HZSM-5 were well fitted to the α-FeOOH standard. The pre-edge and edge energies of all spectra are shown in Table 3 . Small pre-edge at about 7113.2 eV corresponded to the presence of Fe in octahedral geometry [40]. Since no clear evidence in the crystalline structures of α-FeOOH or α-Fe2O3 were determined by XRD. Small clusters (< 4 nm) and/or amorphous form of the iron oxy(hydroxide) such α-FeOOH phase on Fen+-HZSM-5 were suggested by XANES analysis. The presence of small particle α-FeOOH species on the HZSM-5 depending on preparation method was determined in several literatures [41,42]. The intermediate species of (FeO)x-Al were primarily formed on the external framework of HZSM-5. After washing with distilled water, small binuclear hydroxo-iron clusters of α-FeOOH (ca. 80%) could form on the zeolite support [29,43]. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the pristine HZSM-5 and Fen+-HZSM-5 are shown in Fig. 4 . All catalysts showed type I isotherm with hysteresis loops type H4 at relative pressure (P/P0) of 0.45-1.0. These isotherms are generally observed on materials containing micropore and mesopore characters [23]. The present hysteresis loop is due to the existence of slit-shape pores in aggregated zeolite particles [44]. The surface area and total pore volume of the catalysts are shown in Table 1. The present values of Fe2+-HZSM-5 and Fe3+-HZSM-5 were not significantly different from pristine HZSM-5. While, the values obtained from Fe2+/Fe3+-HZSM-5 were slightly lower than the HZSM-5. One possibility of change in these physical properties was discussed by Zhang and a coworker [29]. Decreasing of surface area and pore volume on the iron-supported catalyst might due to migration of the ion exchange irons in zeolite cavity to external surface during the calcination process resulting in the accumulation of the large iron oxide particles. Blocking the large iron oxide particles lead to lower surface area and total pore volume of the iron-supported catalyst. Moreover, the presence of Fe2+/Fe3+ ions potential to form surface complex of –(Fe3+-O-Fe2+OH). Large particles of iron species such as goethite (α-FeOOH) and hematite (α-Fe2O3) could be formed [45]. TEM images of the calcined catalysts are shown in Fig. 5 . Shapes and sizes of the iron structures on the Fen+-HZSM-5 catalysts were varied with different precursors. A granular-like shape of the iron species was observed on Fe2+-HZSM-5 and Fe3+-HZSM-5 with an average particle size of 8 nm. It was clearly seen that the iron particles on Fe3+-HZSM-5 showed high dispersion on the HZSM-5 support. This result might due to high ionic strength of Fe3+ which is strong attraction to oxygen anion of zeolite framework, OF −. In addition, the Fe3+ ion tends to flocculate during gelation process in water rather than Fe2+ ion, hence small particles of the iron oxide are obtained [46]. The result was well corresponding to Fe content observed on Fe3+-HZSM-5 by AAS analysis. The lower the ionic strength of Fe2+ ion; the weaker the adsorption on the active sites (OF −) of zeolite, the iron species could easily migrate to form aggregated particles during calcination. For the Fe2+/Fe3+-HZSM-5 sample, a rod-like shape or nanorod (width = 6 nm) with good dispersion of the Fe species on the HZSM-5 crystal was observed (Fig. 5c). This observed morphology was possibly assigned as the iron (oxy) hydroxide in a goethite (α-FeOOH) form as reported in several literatures [47–49]. The α-FeOOH species containing Fe3+ sites with a poorly crystalline structure could be performed through Fe2+/Fe3+ redox couple in water [50]. The aggregated particles of iron oxides on all samples were obviously larger than 4 nm but those structures could not be investigated by XRD analysis. Therefore, the iron structures presented in Fen+-HZSM-5 were in amorphous phase. 3.2 Iron structures on Fen+-HZSM-5 by EXAFS analysis EXAFS analysis of Fe K-edge provides information on the structural environment of Fe on Fen+-HZSM-5 catalysts. Fig. 6 shows the k3-weigthted Fourier transforms of EXAFS oscillations into R-space. The first shell at ̴1.5 Å was assigned to the contributed Fe-O bond. The second contribution at 2.5 Å was ascribed to considerable scatter and fitted with the Fe-Fe shell. The EXAFS fitting results using Artemis program in IFEFFIT package are listed in Table 4 . Tetrahedral Fe-O geometry was observed on bulk α-Fe2O3 and α-FeOOH structures. The Fe-Fe bond length found on α-FeOOH (3.01 Å) was longer than that of α-Fe2O3 (2.64 Å) indicating the existence of binuclear iron complex on the α-FeOOH structure. The 4-fold Fe-O bonds with bond distances of 2.02 and 2.04 Å were determined on Fe2+-HZSM-5 and Fe3+-HZSM-5 samples, respectively, indicating the tetrahedral geometry Fe-O. On the other hand, two environments of 3-fold Fe-O bonds were observed on the Fe2+/Fe3+-HZSM-5 sample with average bond distances of 2.00 and 2.45 Å. The bond length of 2.45 Å was longer than that generally determined on bulk α-Fe2O3 and α-FeOOH crystalline (Table 4) [51]. This result clearly evidenced a chemical bond between Fe and di-oxygen in the zeolite framework named iron-dioxo species (FO-Fe-OF). In contrast, no iron-dioxo bond was found on the Fe2+-HZSM-5 and Fe3+-HZSM-5 samples. The Fe-Fe bond distances and coordination numbers observed on the Fe2+-HZSM-5 and Fe3+-HZSM-5 samples were closed to α-Fe2O3 structure. Besides, two environment Fe-Fe bonds on Fe2+/Fe3+-HZSM-5 with distances of 2.80 and 3.02 Å were noticeable in the comprising Fe-Fe bond lengths found on bulk α-Fe2O3 and α-FeOOH. The mixture of α-Fe2O3 and α-FeOOH was plausible species presented in the Fe2+/Fe3+-HZSM-5 sample. 3.3 Catalytic activity on phenol hydroxylation Phenol conversion depending on time of the Fen+-HZSM-5 catalysts comparing with bulk iron oxides of α-Fe2O3 and α-FeOOH is shown in Fig. 7 a. Both of bulk α-Fe2O3 and α-FeOOH catalysts showed high phenol conversion of about 75% at 90 min and remained constant for 390 min. While the Fe2+/Fe3+-HZSM-5 was only the iron-supported catalyst showed high phenol conversion of about 80% at 90 min. Moreover, the acquiring turnover number (TON) of the Fe2+/Fe3+-HZSM-5 active catalyst showed the highest value of about 1800 at 150 min (Fig. 7b.). This result indicated a great catalytic performance of the Fe2+/Fe3+-HZSM-5 over bulk iron oxide catalysts of α-Fe2O3 and α-FeOOH. As the iron oxide structures discussed by UV–vis DRS and XAS analysis, the aggregated particles of iron species on Fe2+/Fe3+-HZSM-5 were located mainly on the zeolite surface which easily reacted to the phenol reactant. Moreover, the TON of the Fe2+/Fe3+-HZSM-5 catalysts was improved due to the presence of high active sites of the iron species dispersed on the HZSM-5 support. The strong interaction of the present Fe3+ and oxygen in zeolite framework (OF) could be the reason as described by TEM and N2-adsorption desorption analysis. No catalytic conversion was obtained by Fe2+-HZSM-5 and Fe3+-HZSM-5 as well as pristine HZSM-5. Less catalytic activity of these samples was probably attributed to the presence of isolated Fe3+ in the tetrahedral geometry in the zeolite pore as demonstrated by UV–vis DRS and EXAFS analysis. This tetrahedral-Fe3+ species had lower acidic strength than the octahedral-Fe3+ species, low H2O2 attachment and diffusion ability in reactant migration into zeolite pore had been sequentially taken. The obtained catalytic products showed simultaneous pathways of hydroxylation and over-oxidation or decomposition of phenol. The dihydroxybenzene (DHB) including catechol (CAT) and hydroquinone (HQ) was observed as hydroxylation product while and acetic acid, formic acid and carbon dioxide were obtained as the over-oxidation products [52]. The DHB yield and selectivity to CAT and HQ are shown in Fig. 8 and Table 5 . It was clearly observed that the catalytic selectivity to DHB was significantly attributed to the existent active sites of iron structures on HZSM-5 support. The achieved DHB yield of all catalysts was ordered as α-FeOOH > Fe2+/Fe3+-HZSM-5 > α-Fe2O3. The reaction mechanism of phenol hydroxylation employing iron ions had been previously proposed via Fenton-like reaction [17,53]. In coherent with the reaction mechanism of Cu/MCM-41 catalyst for phenol hydroxylation proposed by Zhang et al. [17], two plausible pathways of the iron-catalyzed phenol hydroxylation by two iron active sites of iron-oxo (Fe-O) and iron-dioxo (O-Fe-O) species were suggested as shown in Scheme 2 . Pathway 1 employed interaction of the iron-oxo species with hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) to produce a FeOOH intermediate, as described in Scheme 2(a). The FeOOH intermediate can react further with H2O2 to form hydroxyl radical ( OH) [9]. Then, phenol reacts with the FeOOH intermediate in the ortho and para position to form CAT and HQ products, respectively. Another hydroxylation pathway catalyzed by the existing iron-dioxo species was proposed as shown in pathway 2. Phenol was firstly adsorbed on iron sites to form phenoxo-iron complex and subsequently oxidized to produce CAT by activated H2O2 (Scheme 2(b)). To confirm the existence of •OH radical in the reaction system, OH radical scavenger of the Fe2+/Fe3+-HZSM-5 catalyst using tert-butanol (t-BuOH) was investigated following the procedure reported by Z. Kozmér et al [54]. No DHB product was detected by this reaction as shown in Figs. 7(a) and 8 . This result confirmed that the yield of DHB product proceeded via intermediate OH radical in the solution as proposed in the reaction mechanism Scheme 2. In this work, the obtained DHB yields and CAT/HQ ratios of the bulk α-Fe2O3 and α-FeOOH (Table 5) were strongly relevant to the existent iron active sites on the ion oxides. High DHB yield and CAT/HQ ratio of α-FeOOH were promoted by the existent binuclear [HO-Fe-O-Fe-OH]2+ clusters containing iron-dioxo species as proven by EXAFS analysis (Section 3.2). Low DHB yield of α-Fe2O3 revealed a side reaction of phenol decomposition due to the presence of iron-oxo (Fe-O) sites on the catalyst. The CAT/HQ ratio given by the Fe2+/Fe3+-HZSM-5 catalyst was higher than that of α-FeOOH. As found in EXAFS analysis section (Table 4), Fe2+/Fe3+-HZSM-5 catalyst contained major component of iron-dioxo species on framework zeolite (FO-Fe-OF). This iron species facilitated phenol hydroxylation through the mechanism pathway 2 (Scheme 2). Long Fe-O bond distances of FO-Fe-OF in Fe2+/Fe3+-HZSM-5 improved the catalytic selective to CAT product. 4 Conclusions Different iron structures on HZSM-5 support were performed by ion exchange with various iron precursors. Isolated Fe3+ or iron-oxo species in tetrahedral geometry proving by UV–vis DRS and EXAFS analysis was found as a major component on Fe2+-HZSM-5 and Fe3+-HZSM-5 catalysts. The iron-oxo species showed the highest dispersion on the Fe3+-HZSM-5 catalyst. Besides, a mixture of iron-oxo and iron-dioxo species was determined as major component on the Fe2+/Fe3+-HZSM-5 catalyst with high particle agglomeration. The presence of iron-oxo and iron-dioxo species played roles as active sites for phenol hydroxylation. The Fe2+/Fe3+-HZSM-5 catalyst showed higher TON for phenol hydroxylation than the bulk α-Fe2O3 and α-FeOOH catalysts. The improving of CAT product by exiting of iron dioxo species on the Fe2+/Fe3+-HZSM-5 catalysts was observed. Acknowledgements Center for Innovation in Chemistry (PERCH-CIC). coredata.dc:description: Iron-containing HZSM-5 zeolite (Fen+-HZSM-5) are performed by ion exchange method with varying iron precursors of Fe2+, Fe3+ and equivalent molar of Fe2+/Fe3+. The Fen+-HZSM-5 materials are used as catalysts for phenol hydroxylation in the presence of H2O2. Bulk-iron oxides of α-Fe2O3 and α-FeOOH are synthesized via hydrothermal method for catalytic comparison to Fen+-HZSM-5. The iron structures on the Fen+-HZSM-5 catalysts are determined using UV–vis DRS and EXAFS techniques. The iron species found in the Fe2+-HZSM-5 and Fe3+-HZSM-5 catalysts is an isolated Fe3+ ion in tetrahedral geometry. Iron-oxo bonds with oxygen in zeolite framework (Fe-OF) are identified on both catalysts. On the other hand, Fe-O bond distances and coordination number on Fe2+/Fe3+-HZSM-5 exhibit the mixture of iron-oxo and iron-dioxo species (FO-Fe-OF) in octahedral geometry. The present iron species in the Fe2+/Fe3+-HZSM-5 catalyst show a significant improvement of the turnover number (TON) for phenol hydroxylation in comparison to the bulk α-Fe2O3 and α-FeOOH catalysts. Moreover, the existent iron-dioxo species on the Fe2+/Fe3+-HZSM-5 catalyst enhances catalytic selectivity to catechol product.
coredata.dc:title: Formation of iron active species on HZSM-5 catalysts by varying iron precursors for phenol hydroxylation
